characters: THE MEMORY BULKHEAD BURSTS OPEN AND... A MUZZLE FLASH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Postage stamp size. Clothes on the line. The sunlight cut by the cramped crowd of houses. We're already PULLING AWAY FROM the backs of two men. Drinking beer, smoking Luckys and sharing a laugh. An 11-year-old boy leans on a street hockey stick, watches them. JIMMY MARCUS, unspent energy coiled tight in his chest. His friend SEAN DEVINE steps over, holds up an orange street hockey ball.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG SEAN
dialogues.text: Got it. Jimmy's attention is fixed on his and Sean's fathers.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG SEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, Jimmy. Sean punches him in the arm. As Jimmy looks hard over, Sean wiggles the ball, raises his eyebrows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wearing a Red Sox cap, DAVE BOYLE stands eagerly before a makeshift chicken wire goalie net as Jimmy and Sean whack away at the orange ball with their street hockey sticks. As it bounces toward Dave, he takes an arcing swing at it. Connects. The ball sails.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG DAVE
dialogues.text: Save! Sean and Jimmy watch as the ball bounces into the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sewer... They charge off after it.

dialogues.speaker: GUTTER
dialogues.text: The ball rolls, disappears down a storm drain. BOOM UP to see the boys arriving too late to stop it. Jimmy and Sean look back at Dave bringing up the rear. Looking guilty.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG DAVE
dialogues.text: Sorry, guys. (smiling) Guess I don't know my own strength.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG JIMMY
dialogues.text: Yeah, Dave, that must be it. As Sean gets down on his hands and knees to look down into the sewer, Jimmy looks up and down the street.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know what would be cool?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG DAVE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG JIMMY
dialogues.text: Driving a car. Sean looks up from the storm drain.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know. Just around the block.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG SEAN
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG JIMMY
dialogues.text: Anyone on this street keep their keys in their car? Sean and Dave exchange a look. Jimmy's crazy.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG SEAN
dialogues.text: ( (standing) I steal a car, my dad'll kill me.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG JIMMY
dialogues.text: Just around the block. Who said steal?  Sean shakes his head "no." Jimmy heaves a sigh. Jimmy walks to where sawhorses have been set up. City crews have replaced several squares of sidewalk. Yellow caution tape is tied to the sawhorses creating a barricade. Jimmy snaps the tape by walking right through it. Jimmy grabs a stick and starts to write his name. Sean and Dave step up, look over his shoulder, J-I-M-M-Y. Jimmy looks back over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your dad kill you for writing your name, too? Sean takes the stick, squats down. S-E-A-N. Jimmy smiles.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now it'll be there forever.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG DAVE
dialogues.text: Me, too. Forever. Dave takes the stick, starts his own name by the other two. D-A -- A little SQUEAL as a CAR lurches to a stop across from them. A dark, plain Plymouth. The DRIVER gets out. Crewcut, white shirt and black tie, a gold badge and cuffs clipped to his belt buckle. There's another man in the passenger seat. Hard to make out through the watery reflection of trees in the glass. Hard to tell whether he's wearing a priest's collar or a turtleneck. The kids look at the badge. The Driver crooks a finger at them, wriggles it toward his cheat until they step over.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Let me ask you something. He looks from the sidewalk to the stick in Dave's hand.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You brats think it's okay to destroy municipal property? No answer. The Driver cups a hand behind his ear.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG DAVE
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG SEAN
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: No what?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG JIMMY
dialogues.text: Sir...

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: You're the hard case of the group, huh? A pack of punks, huh? The Driver looks at Sean.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You live around here? Not intimidated, Sean points at the house behind them.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG SEAN
dialogues.text: Right there. The Driver's eyes flicker up toward the house. For just an instant we see the fear and doubt in them. Then, deciding, he looks hard at Dave. Dave is near tears.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: How 'bout you? Where do you live, son?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG DAVE
dialogues.text: Rester Street.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Your mother home? Dave starts to cry. He nods.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're going to go have a talk with her. Tell her what her punk kid's been up to. The Driver opens the back door of the Plymouth.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get in. Dave doesn't move, looks at Jimmy. Sean leans out, notices the trash collected on the floor of the back seat. A strange, lost moment. The spell is broken as the Driver slaps his hand on the roof of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the fuck inside! Bawling, Dave climbs in. The Driver points a finger at Jimmy and Sean.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go tell your mothers what you've been up to. And don't let me catch you shits ruining my sidewalks again. The street goes mute with the SLAMMING of CAR DOORS. And then the car is driving off. Dave looks back at them out the window, his head darkened by distance and shadows. And then he's gone. Leaving Sean and Jimmy behind. In the b.g., VOICES, each more panicked than the last.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Weren't there three of you? Where's Dave?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: The cops took Dave? What cops?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Oh my God. Oh my God. Dave.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Damaged goods. Even if they find him alive, he'll never be the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinged and cracked with twenty years of age. There are the names: Jimmy, Sean and D-A. Forever.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE
dialogues.text: COME OFF the sidewalk to allow a MAN, wearing a Red Sox cap, late 30s, walking down the sidewalk with an eight- year-old boy (MICHAEL) wearing a little league uniform.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (MAN)
dialogues.text: You took some good swings today.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Dad, I struck out.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Good swings though. That's what counts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll never be a good ballplayer.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Hey, you're my son. Me. Dave Boyle, star shortstop of Don Bosco High School 1978 to 1982. You're going to be a great ballplayer. Michael's not so sure. Dave sees something ahead, points.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See that gutter drain? I used to play on this street when I was a kid. That drain used to swallow every ball we had. They start walking again, Michael listening eagerly.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Baseballs, street hockey balls, pinkies. If we could get the manhole cover off, there'd be a thousand balls down there.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Really? Let's try. As they near it, Dave spots the sidewalk square with the names in it. His good mood shifts a bit.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: The Driver/cop slamming his palm on the hood of the Plymouth. Young Dave blinking back tears. Dave looks at his son, finally answers...

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Maybe tomorrow. Let's get home before Mom starts to worry. They continue. As Dave looks back over his shoulder...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty years old. Sitting at a small desk surrounded by shelved stock: cigarettes, corn flakes, soda... Going over some order sheets, Jimmy's lost in thought. Different from when he was a kid, this is a 1,000 yard stare.  Beyond, through a half-open curtain, a CASH REGISTER RINGS, a couple kids working behind the counter. One of the clerks, PETE, 21, steps into the back.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Hey, Jimmy. Jimmy. He waves a hand in front of Jimmy's face.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Earth to Mr. Marcus. Jimmy snaps back to reality.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: What do you want now, Pete?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Like I'm Mr. Needy all of a sudden. We're out of Marlboros and Winstons are looking grim.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: So that's lost profit. And more profits means I get a raise. Pete grabs a carton of cigarettes and heads out.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If the Surgeon General calls, you're my alibi. As Pete exits, Jimmy tries to focus on his order forms. Then KATIE is in the door looking at him. Nineteen, beautiful, Jimmy's daughter. She smiles as she watches him. He finally feels her eyes on him.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Going out tonight with Eve and Diane. And it's seven-thirty.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Don't be out late. It's your sister's first communion tomorrow. Christ, I sound like, I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Someone's father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Not mine, but somebody's. She leans in, kisses him on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Later, Daddy. He watches her breeze out. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Later...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BELL TINGLES as Katie walks out the front door. Humming to herself. In a great mood. She gets into her car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katie STARTS the CAR, nearly screams as someone sits up from the back seat. Then she recognizes:

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Brendan. You scared the shit out of me. In the back seat BRENDAN HARRIS. Nineteen, he loves Katie Marcus like crazy. Brendan is an anthem for her.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Sorry. But I didn't want your dad to see me waiting.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: He sees you sneaking into my car, he'll shoot you... And they're kissing. Like nineteen-year-olds.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: (between breaths) What'll he do if he sees this?

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Shoot you -- then kill you.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: It's been six hours. I had to see you. As the passion increases, Katie suddenly breaks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to be late for Diane and Eve.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Tomorrow. Like we planned.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Tomorrow... They kiss again. Brendan ducks at the STORE BELL. It's a customer exiting.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Drop me around the corner. Katie laughs, drives. As the car turns the corner, we look up to the TOBIN BRIDGE. A gloomy old erector set spanning the Mystic River. THUMPING with the passing CARS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Southbound lanes swarming with state police. The sight of a road-rage killing. Absolutely senseless.

dialogues.speaker: HANDCUFFED MAN
dialogues.text: He kept cutting me off. He kept cutting me off. SEAN DEVINE is here, now a detective with the staties. Grown up into a good-looking adult. He looks down at the tenements of Faneuil Heights and the East Bucky Flats. He's joined by his partner, WHITEY POWERS.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: Guy won't stop confessing. We should pull a lawyer out of one of these B.M.W.s. Sean keeps staring down over the rail.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What'cha looking at?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: My old neighborhood. A FEMALE TROOPER joins them. Her uniform not drab enough to hide how sexy she is. She stares straight at Sean.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE TROOPER
dialogues.text: We're done, Sean, but I can stick around if you need anything.  10.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: No. We're fine.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE TROOPER
dialogues.text: A few of us are going to the Can Tab after.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: I don't think so, Jan. Thanks. Disappointed, she heads off. Whitey watches her ass.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: The wife left you, what, six months ago.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: So, Jenny Coughlin there, Jenny with the bod', the voice, the cuffs, the girl makes gay guys reconsider their orientation.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: What's your point?

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: She is trying to bed you and you don't even blink.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: I'm married, Whitey.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: You haven't even talked to Lauren in six months.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: She calls all the time.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: And doesn't speak. Weirdest fucking thing I ever heard. Sean looks back out at the neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: One of these days the phone'll ring and she'll talk. I'll pick it up and she'll tell me why she left.  11.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: Maybe she's waiting for you to say something. INT. McGILL'S BAR -- JUKEBOX -- NIGHT Where DIANE CESTRA drops a quarter in the slot. Pressing D-3, she looks back and smiles at her friends, EVE PIGEON and Katie Marcus. It's "Brown Eyed Girl" as VAN MORRISON starts: "Hey where did we go...?"

dialogues.speaker: BAR
dialogues.text: Diane unsteadily rejoins her friends. A girl's night out as they laugh, swig beer and sing-a-long with the music.

dialogues.speaker: FURTHER DOWN BAR
dialogues.text: Dave Boyle sits hunched over a beer with a FRIEND, watching the Red Sox game on the TV.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Come on. Double play. At the sound of a cheer (not for the Sox), the Friend looks back over his shoulder, nudges Dave in the ribs.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: You believe those chicks? As Dave turns to follow his gaze... Katie and Eve have climbed onto the bar, dance on top of it. Katie the class of the two. Some of the guys cheer, others watch with a sad yearning, know it's not for them. Dave cocks his head, watches Katie. Smiles to himself as her hair falls over her eyes like a veil.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ain't that Jimmy Marcus's girl?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Yeah... We CLOSE ON Dave as he seems suddenly lost in the moment.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I remember when she was a kid.  12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CELESTE BOYLE, 37, in her nightgown, leans against the door frame, looking in at her sleeping son Michael. She looks sad. At the click of the front door lock, she looks up.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: Dave's closing it shut behind him when Celeste steps around the corner, concern still overriding anger.

dialogues.speaker: CELESTE
dialogues.text: Dave, it's three in the morning. Where have you been? I was -- She stops short as she sees there's blood all over him. He stands there embarrassed, like he was ten years old.

dialogues.speaker: CELESTE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I tucked up. The guy tried to mug me, right? So, so I swung on him. And he sliced me. He clutches at his side. Celeste sees that it's crimson.

dialogues.speaker: CELESTE
dialogues.text: (stepping forward) Jesus, Dave, you have to go to the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: No, no. It's not that deep. It just bled like hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave, shirt off, holds his arm up, grimaces as Celeste dabs hydrogen peroxide on a sweeping gash along his rib cage.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I'm walking to my car and this guy comes up to me, asks for a light. I say I don't smoke. Guy says neither does he. So my heart starts clocking a buck fifty ‘cause there's no one around but me and him.  13.

dialogues.speaker: CELESTE
dialogues.text: Oh God.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: That's when I see the knife and he says, "Your wallet or your life, bitch. I'm leaving with one of 'em.,

dialogues.speaker: CELESTE
dialogues.text: That's what he said?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Yeah. So, so then I try to brush past him and that's when he slices me. Celeste, can I tell the fucking story? She touches his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: CELESTE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, baby. He kisses her hand.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I went fucking nuts on him, babe. I went off. I bashed his head on the parking lot. I, I might have killed him, honey.

dialogues.speaker: CELESTE
dialogues.text: Killed him? Dave nods. He's serious. Celeste looks at him. Eyes wide, face pale and sweaty. His breath starts to get a little ragged as he looks back. He's really scared.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: It makes you feel alone. Hurting someone.

dialogues.speaker: CELESTE
dialogues.text: But you had to. Celeste embraces him. Over her shoulder:

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: It makes you feel... alien. Celeste looks at him, suddenly filling with strength.

dialogues.speaker: CELESTE
dialogues.text: Baby, you hop in the shower. (beat) I'll take care of your clothes.  14. Dave's not sure what that means. Neither are we.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: CELESTE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy looks tough even when he's sleeping. His wife ANNABETH snoozes beside him. The bedside clock reads: 6:02. The PHONE starts to RING. Jimmy answers, bleary.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (over phone) I'm in the weeds here at the store, Jimmy. I need some help. Jimmy looks at the clock.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You and Katie can't handle six, how you going to handle eight when the first church crowd comes in?

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: That's the thing, Katie ain't here.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: No? Hold on. Jimmy rolls to his feet. MOVE WITH him as he walks down...

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The Sunday paper's still bundled, doughnut guy's honking his horn. He looks in her room. Her bed is empty and made.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I'll be there in ten minutes, Pete. Call Sal and see if he can make it by eight instead of ten.  15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy pulls on his clothes. Annabeth watches from bed.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABETH
dialogues.text: She no-shows at work, what if she no- shows at church?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I'm sure she'll make it.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABETH
dialogues.text: Yeah. She's going to screw up this day, too.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: What other day has she screwed up lately? Annabeth puts up her hands, doesn't want to fight.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABETH
dialogues.text: You got two other daughters. Don't forget it.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: One hour. I'll still be back before anyone gets out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy arrives to a morning rush. Folks coming off the night shift: Cops, nurses from St. Regina's and a few working girls, all coming off the same battlefield together. Pete looks up, smiles in relief as Jimmy takes up a position by the cash register and lottery machine. Jimmy punches out tickets, RINGS UP at the REGISTER. He also takes the phone off the wall behind him, dials.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hey, Drew, it's Jimmy. Sorry to wake you, I'm looking for Katie.

dialogues.speaker: DREW, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I think she's here, yeah. Lemme go check. Hold on. Jimmy's relieved. First time he even knew he was worried. As he bags a sale, smiles across at a customer.  16.

dialogues.speaker: DREW, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Sorry. It was Diane Cestra slept over. But no Katie. Eve said Katie dropped them off at one. Didn't say where she was going.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Okay, man, I'll track her down.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: She seeing anyone maybe?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Nineteen-year-old girls, Drew? Who could keep a tally?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: That's the cold truth. As Jimmy hangs up the phone, the BELL over the door RINGS and the first Sunday mass crowd rolls in. A shitload of blue hair old ladies. Pete looks over at Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Welcome to hell... As they surge toward the counter in a wave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the blue hairs exit, the CASH REGISTER DING is replaced by CHURCH BELLS RINGING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy pulls another pot of coffee from the brewer. Pete appears from out front.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I'll take the hookers over the old ladies any day. Mind if I step out back and grab a smoke?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Fuck, Pete, smoke the whole pack.  17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BELL RINGS. Jimmy looks up as Brendan Harris and his little brother Silent Ray enter. Ray carries his street hockey stick, a blankness living in his face. Brendan clocks Jimmy with a brief look of surprise before turning down an aisle. He talks to his brother with sign language. His brother's hands flying back answers.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (frowns ) Help you, Brendan?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Uh, no, Mr. Marcus, just getting some of that tea my mom likes.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Barry's. Next aisle over.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Oh thanks. Hands fly again as Brendan and Silent Ray move an aisle over. As Pete returns from his smoke.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: What time's Sal getting here?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Any time now. Jimmy sighs, looks out the front window. Brendan comes to the counter with his tea. Pete steps over.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That it, Brendan?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: And a Globe. While Jimmy is preoccupied and as Pete RINGS UP the sale.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So's, ah, I thought Katie worked on Sundays.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You sweet on my man's daughter, Brendan?  18.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: (laughs ) No, no, no. I was just wondering, you know, because usually I see her here.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Oh... Not too happy to pick up Jimmy's attention, Brendan gets his change and starts out.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nice seeing you. Come on, Ray. Ray, his back to his brother when he spoke, turns and starts after him. Jimmy stares after them as they go.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Can I ask you something, Jimmy?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Shoot.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Why do you hate that kid so bad?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: It's not hate, man. But come on, don't you find that mute little fucker a little spooky?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Not Silent Ray. Brendan. Jimmy looks over at Pete.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nice kid. Uses sign language with his brother even if he doesn't have to. It's like, so he won't feel alone. But, Jimmy, you look at Brendan like you're two steps from slicing off his nose and feeding it to him.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: No. Really?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Straight up.  19. Jimmy looks back out the window at the receding brothers, hands flying. Then old man Sal crosses the view, headed for the store. Jimmy starts untying his work apron.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Here comes Sal. About fucking time, too...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tenements, the Tobin Bridge, beat-up baseball diamonds and rusty playgrounds. OVER it all, a 911 Operator answers a call:

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: 9-1-1, police services. What is the nature of your emergency?

dialogues.speaker: BOY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There's like this car with blood in it and, ah, the door's open -

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What's the location of the car?

dialogues.speaker: BOY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Uh, Sydney Street in the Flats. By Pen Park. Me and my friend found it. The AERIAL VIEW PASSES OVER Pen Channel, the abandoned drive-in screen on one side of the park and then Pen Park itself. A littered, depressing site.

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Son, what's your name?

dialogues.speaker: BOY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (to someone else) He wants to know her name.

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Your name. What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: BOY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We're so fucking out of here. Good luck. CLICK. We've OVER the Sydney Street entrance to the park. There's a car down there, door open, front tires against the curb. As we CONTINUE PAST it and INTO the mostly abandoned houses across the way...  20.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dispatch, this is unit thirty-three. We're going to need a crime scene tech or two and you might want to notify homicide.

dialogues.speaker: DISPATCHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Have you found a body, thirty-three? Over.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No, but looks of this car, we'll find one sooner or later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue sawhorses stamped °BOSTON POLICE DEPARTMENT® cordon off the scene. The crime scene services van is parked further down. Sean Devine pulls up in an unmarked, gets out. He's met by his partner Whitey.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: Hey, bad boy. This should be the city's but... (points) Park's reservation land. State jurisdiction, not city. If the body's in there, it's our case. Police are already walking through the underbrush.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: (wincing) How much evidence you think they've destroyed so far? As they start toward the car, one of the cops adds local color as we hear him talk to his buddies.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: The Parker Hill vic, right? Walked into the E.R. at M.G.H. on his own, steak knife sticking out of his collarbone, asking the nurse where they keep the Coke machine round this bitch.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: She tell him? They all laugh, but Sean. It's too goddamn early.  21.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: What do we got on the car so far?

dialogues.speaker: CSS TECH
dialogues.text: We found the reg in the glove box. Owner is Katherine Marcus. Sean reacts hard to the name.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: You know her?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Maybe. Might be the daughter of a guy I know.

dialogues.speaker: CSS TECH
dialogues.text: We found a wallet and license ina backpack on the floor. She was nineteen.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Fuck. That's her.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: Is it a problem? You close with the guy? Sean waves it off. He's staying on the case.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: When we were kids. Now? Just a hello around the neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: Nineteen... Fuck, man. He's in for a world of hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her hands pressed together, dressed in a white dress with a white veil. Walking up the aisle in a procession of twenty other children. First communion.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY AND ANNABETH
dialogues.text: Stand with their other daughter, Sara. Look back to watch their daughter come up the aisle. As Nadine's about to pass them, Annabeth whispers:  22.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABETH
dialogues.text: Do not make her laugh. As Nadine passes, she chances a look over at her father. He waves from his hip, wiggles his eyebrows. Nadine smiles huge. Annabeth digs an elbow into his ribs.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: What? As she continues to the altar, Jimmy looks back over his shoulder. Really hoping to see Katie arrive at the last minute. But she's not going to make it.

dialogues.speaker: CSS TECH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Door was ajar when we found it. Headlights on. You got blood on the driver door speaker...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean looks the car over, puts the initial crime together.

dialogues.speaker: CSS TECH
dialogues.text: More blood on top of the steering wheel and around a bullet hole punched through the driver's seat back at shoulder level. As more police arrive to search, Sean looks at a fresh dent in the driver's door, past to the weeds, takes a stab.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Perp stood outside the car. The Marcus girl slams him with the door. Perp gets a round off, hits her in the shoulder, maybe the biceps? She runs for it. (points into park) Through those trampled weeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Nadine solemnly receives her first communion. Annabeth, near tears, leans into Jimmy, whispers in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABETH
dialogues.text: Our baby. My God, Jimmy, our baby.  23. Jimmy puts his arm around her, kisses the side of her head. As she leans into him a little more... FLASHBACK --— CELLAR Young Dave curled up whimpering on a pile of rags. Looking up in terror as a DOOR BANGS open at the top of the stairs. And as feet start ominously down...

dialogues.speaker: DAVE BOYLE
dialogues.text: The man, waking up with a start in his bed. INT. BOYLE APARTMENT -- KITCHEN -- DAY Michael sits at the table eating cereal. Celeste is at the counter flipping through the last of three different newspapers. She looks up as Dave enters, yawning, just rolled out of bed. He goes to the refrigerator without an apparent care in the world. CELESTE Dave... He looks over, clocks the look on her face. He steps over.

dialogues.speaker: CELESTE
dialogues.text: (low) There's nothing in the papers. I checked three times.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: It was late. Real late. He kisses her forehead. She manages a smile.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Morning, Mikey. You up for hitting some whiffle ball?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nylon triangle hangs from a branch. Just under a footbridge over Pen Channel. The CSS Tech pinches it off with a pair of tweezers. It's got blood on it. Sean and Whitey crouch by the arch. There's a woman's shoe there along with several similar footprints.  24.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: I'd say she might've hid here a bit. Killer shows and she bolts to the other side, takes off running again. Sean looks out to where the water in the channel widens out.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Better call some divers while we're at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids flow outside through the front of the church, the adults following behind. Nadine spots her father, makes a break for him.

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: Daddy, Daddy! Jimmy scoops her in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Baby!

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: This dress itches.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: It's itching me and I'm not even wearing it. Jimmy looks over his shoulder, smiles at Annabeth and Sara. They beam back. A moment of perfect happiness, until... A state POLICE CRUISER SLAMS around the corner of Buckingham Avenue. Jimmy whips around, matches as it goes wide into the left lane of Roseclair, rear TIRE SLAPPING the median strip, SIREN SLICING the morning air. It's followed an instant later by a black unmarked, cutting the ninety-degree turn at forty miles an hour. Two more cop cars zip under the overpass, take the entrance road into Pen Park. Jimmy lowers Nadine to the ground.  25. And he knows, feels it in his blood with a sudden mean certainty, a sense of things falling miserably into place.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Katie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like a riot waiting room. Cops, in the bushes, cops at the sawhorses, cops everywhere. K-9 German shepherds being walked out of a van. The crowd of onlookers growing. Jimmy steps up, is spotted by ED DEVEAU who's opening a bag of M&Ms with his teeth. As a POLICE HELICOPTER BUZZES by.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Hey, Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: What's up, Ed?

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: They got Sydney blocked off, Crescent, all the way to Dunboy. Boo Bear Durkin said he saw frogmen going into the Pen. Why you all decked out?

dialogues.speaker: ED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what the hell you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Just curious I guess. Jimmy spots the clot of cops around a car, moves laterally for a better view. He gets it, sees it's Katie's. Jimmy starts forward, pushes through one end of the sawhorse, is almost there before two cops block him. As they babble official speak...

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's my daughter's cart

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean looking for something, anything. Whitey steps over.  26.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: We got dogs sniffing something by the old drive-in screen. Want to take a walk over? Sean nods. His WALKIE-TALKIE SURGES TO LIFE.

dialogues.speaker: WALKIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Trooper Devine.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: (into walkie) Yeah, go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: WALKIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We got a guy out on Sydney, says he's the father of the girl.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Shit... (into walkie) You got a psychologist on scene yet?

dialogues.speaker: WALKIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: En route.

dialogues.speaker: WALKIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He's asking for you, Devine. Says he knows you. Sean looks to Whitey who just shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: WALKIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He's not taking no for an answer. And he's got some guys with him.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: What guys?

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Scary-looking guys.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: The Savage brothers. Christ. (into walkie) I'm on my way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy's there with three of the Savage brothers: NICK, VAL and Kevin. His brothers-in-law. Jail-yard stares and hair triggers. They shout across the barrier at the cops.  27.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: That's our niece in there, you dumb prick pieces of shit!

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Hey. We're doing our job.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: All due respect, the doughnut shop's that way. Jimmy standing a little alone, watching. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Val, ease up! Nick. Nickie. Take Kevin and go to Drew Pigeon's. Talk to his daughter and her friend. Katie was out with them last night.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (nodding) Kevin, let's go!

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: And hey, these girls are friends. Don't get hard on them, but get answers. As Nick and Kevin head off, Sean arrives, greeting Jimmy with as big a smile as he can muster.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Jimmy, hey, man.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Is she in there, Sean?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: We don't know. All we're doing right now is looking.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: So let us in. We can help look. Sean doesn't even look at Val, just keeps his eyes on Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Sorry. As soon as I know anything, you'll know.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: That's my daughter's car.  28.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: I know. I --

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (panic rising) My daughter's car. It's got blood in it. They brought fucking dogs in. Why do you got dogs looking for my daughter, Sean?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Because we're looking. Okay, Jimmy? Right now all she is is missing. Okay? As Jimmy nods, Sean's WALKIE CRACKLES TO LIFE right.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Trooper Devine, we got something.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Say again.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Sergeant Powers said you need to get in here. Uh, ASAP, like right now.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Your location?

dialogues.speaker: RADIO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The drive-in screen. And, man, it's a fucking mess. Sean looks back at Jimmy who's just about coming out of his skin. Sean looks to the cops.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Don't let him through. As Sean hurries off, Jimmy steps back alongside Val.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You still got those bolt cutters in your trunk?

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: Guy's gotta make a living, Jim. Jimmy goes the other way, Val following.  29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celeste washes dishes, scrubbing away like it means something. A portable TV on the counter. Suddenly: the TV newsroom.

dialogues.speaker: TV ANCHOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We interrupt to bring you a breaking story. A massive search is under way for a woman missing in the Buckingham Flats. A news chopper POV. The car and park and police below. Celeste watches transfixed, soap dripping from her hands.

dialogues.speaker: TV ANCHOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: All we know so far is that there are signs of foul play in a car found abandoned outside Pen Park. Police have... As the anchor drones, Celeste goes to the window, takes a vertiginous look into the yard below. Dave is playing ball with Michael. As they laugh and pal around, Celeste looks momentarily ill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steps lead down to a door on the side of the screen. CSS flashbulbs pop. Whitey looks in, jots notes. An assistant MEDICAL EXAMINER is down on his knees looking at something. Plus a platoon of uniformed troopers and Boston PD blues. A BABY-FACED COP stares away from the action, being comforted by his partner as Sean passes on his way in.

dialogues.speaker: BABY-FACE
dialogues.text: I never saw anything like it. Man, this is... this is... Sean sees the blood, already circled, on the steps leading down. A path is made for him. As he reaches the door, Whitey looks back, meets Sean's gaze, looks ten years older. Sean's view widens as he sees between the ME and CSS tech. A body is scrunched there, the space between the walls no more than three feet wide.  30. Katie Marcus sits with her back against the wall on the right, her feet pushed up hard on the wall to the left. Like a fetus in some horrific womb. A torn sock hangs around her left ankle, a simple black shoe with a flat heel is on her right foot. Her jacket is torn, her pants mud-stained. Blood is everywhere. Like a red rain, it's in her hair, dots her cheeks, stains her clothes in red strings. Katie's knees are pressed to her chest, her right elbow propped on her right knee, a clenched fist up by her ear trying to keep some awful sound at bay. Her eyes are clenched shut as tight as her fist. Stop it, just stop it, the body says. Stop it, please. Sean steps in, crouches. Whitey fills the space behind him.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: That her? As gently as he can, Sean uses his forefinger to move back a heavy strand of hair. He looks at Katie a moment.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: We'll have the father do a positive at the morgue.

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL EXAMINER
dialogues.text: Blood's from a split on the crown of her head. She was beaten with some kind of stick. But that didn't kill her. She was shot a second time. Looks like a .38. Sean hasn't really heard any of it.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: What the fuck am I going to tell him. Hey guess what, Jimmy? God said you owed another marker. He came to collect. Sudden SHOUTS from outside, the K-9 DOGS BARK like mad. Sean springs up. As he and Whitey turn outside.  31.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVE-IN SCREEN
dialogues.text: Eight uniforms and two plainclothes converge on Jimmy and Val as they burst from the trees. Val goes down snarling almost right away. But Jimmy's too quick. He's almost to the screen when he stumbles. A young trooper, all head and high school tight-end, body-tackles him, lands on top of him. As he pins Jimmy's arm back...

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Hey! Hey! It's the father. Just pull him back. As Sean turns back to the screen:

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Sean! Look at me, Sean! Sean looks back at him. Jimmy arches up under the young cop's weight. Another cop helps hold him.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You find her? Is it her? Is it? Sean is motionless. He holds Jimmy's eyes with his own, locking them until Jimmy's surging stare sees what Sean has just seen. And he knows it's over, his worst fear realized. And Jimmy screams. Love and rage in equal quantities. It shreds the birds from the trees. It ECHOES into the Pen Channel. Ropes of spit shoot from his mouth. Screaming. Sean turns away, looks back in at Katie. It's awful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy sits in a straight-back wooden chair. Waiting, head back, hands folded. He looks up at FOOTSTEPS. Annabeth is shown in by a young officer. Jimmy rises. She's still wearing her lavender dress from the communion. She steps into his arms, presses her face into his chest.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABETH
dialogues.text: No one said anything. Right?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: What do you mean, baby?  32.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABETH
dialogues.text: You haven't seen her yet, right? It might not be her, right? Jimmy doesn't answer, doesn't know what to say. Annabeth looks up at him. Desperate, wretched with hope.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jimmy... Jimmy, please. Please.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Please what, honey? What?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABETH
dialogues.text: Oh, please, Jimmy. No. No. Sobbing, she crumbles into him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PUSH IN ON Katie. She lies on a metal table. Her eyes are closed and she's missing a shoe. Jimmy enters from the other way. Sean a step behind him. Jimmy stops short, opens his mouth to speak, but nothing comes out. Sean puts a hand on the small of his back.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's her. That's Katie. That's my daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean sits across from Jimmy and Annabeth. A beat of surreal silence before Whitey arrives with four coffees.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: Fresh-brewed.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: We need to work a timeline. It's the details, the little things that can make a case. Things you forget after a day or two. Annabeth nods that she understands. Jimmy's a little in shock. Lost a moment, then he looks to Sean.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You ever think how one choice can change your life? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I heard Hitler's mother almost aborted him but bailed at the last minute. You know?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: What do you mean, Jimmy?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Say you or me got in that car instead of Dave Boyle.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: What car?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: I'm losing you here, Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: If I'd got in that car, life would be a different thing. My first wife, Marita, Katie's mother? She was beautiful. Regal. You know the way some Latin women can be? And she knew it. You had to have balls to even go near her. And I did. Eighteen years old, the two of us, and she was carrying Katie. Here's the thing, Sean, if I had gotten in that car, I most likely would've ended up a basket case. I never would have had the juice to ask out Marita and we never would've had Katie. And Katie, then, would never have been murdered. You see what I'm saying?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: You ever see Dave around?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABETH
dialogues.text: He married my cousin. Celeste. Sean nods again. Whitey finally gets things on track.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: What time did Katie get home from work yesterday?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABETH
dialogues.text: Around four-thirty.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: Anything unusual? Out of the ordinary about her?  34.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABETH
dialogues.text: No. She sat with me and the girls while we ate. She was having dinner with her friends. Whitey checks his pad.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: Eve Pigeon and Diane Cestra?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABETH
dialogues.text: (nodding) Katie talked to Nadine about her Communion, then she was on the phone in her room a bit, and then, about eight, she left.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: Do you know who she talked to?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABETH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: Would you mind if we subpoenaed the phone company records to that line? Annabeth looks over at Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: No. Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: Mr. Marcus, you spent a good part of Saturday with your daughter at the store, correct?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Yes and no. I was mostly in back.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: You remember anything odd? A confrontation with a customer?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: No. She was herself. She was happy. She --

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: No, nothing.  35.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: The littlest thing is something right now.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: When she was little, right after her mother had died, I had just gotten out of prison and I could never leave her alone. Whether she ended up crying or not, she'd get this look. Like she was preparing to never see you again. For a few seconds on Saturday, she looked at me that way. Whitey starts to write this down. His shock

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, it was just a look.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: It's info. I collect it until a few pieces fit. Little things. You say you were in prison?

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm just asking.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Sixteen years ago. Two years at Deer Island for robbery. Is that going to help you catch my daughter's killer? I mean, I'm just asking. dissolving, Jimmy stares hard at Whitey.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Okay, let's forget it and get back to the point. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: The point.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Outside that look Katie gave you, was there anything else? Jimmy takes his convict-in-the-yard stare off Whitey, sips some coffee, does his genuine best to think.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Um, this kid... No, that was this morning.  36.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: What? Remember, little things.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Neighborhood, kid, Brendan Harris, came in this morning, asked if Katie was around, like he expected to see her. But they barely knew each other.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: You're sure? Could they have been dating?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Why are you so sure?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Hey, Sean, what the fuck? You're going to grill me? A father knows.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: Mrs. Marcus? Who was she seeing?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABETH
dialogues.text: No one right now. As far as we know. I mean... knew. The past/present tense is all it took. As Annabeth fights back tears, Jimmy squeezes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I'll answer everything you got tomorrow, but we got to go. We got two girls waiting at home wondering where their sister is.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: There'll be a trooper downstairs to drive you home. If you think of anything, give us a call. Whitey hands Jimmy his card. Jimmy nods good-bye, helps Annabeth away. Sean and Whitey watch as they head off.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He said you almost got in some car when you were kids. What was that about?  37.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: We, shit, well, there was this car. Me and Jimmy and a kid named Dave Boyle were playing in front of my house. And this car came up the street and took Dave away.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: Abduction?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Guys pretended to be cops. Convinced Dave to get in the car. They had him for four days before he managed to get away.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: They catch the guys?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: One died, the other got busted about a year later and went the noose route in his cell.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: Your buddy, Marcus. Moment I laid eyes on him, I knew he'd done time. They never lose the tension, you know? It settles in their shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: He just lost his daughter, man. Maybe that's what settled in his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: No. That's in his stomach. Notice how he kept grimacing? Seen it a million times. The shoulders, though, that's prison.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: As Young Dave desperately pounds. Trying to get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Along the Mystic River. Dave Boyle walks, hands thrust in his pockets. Prostitutes blend in the shadows of doorways, lean into the windows of IDLING CARS. Some take a half-step in the streetlight to show Dave what they got.  38. But he continues forward, not interested. Last of all, a kid, a boy, fifteen at the most. Lighting a smoke, he looks up, smiles around the cigarette. Dave stops. The kid's eyes suddenly widen in recognition and he bolts. Dave follows a few steps, but the kid's already disappeared into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I just want to talk to you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two uniformed TROOPERS search. Under the mattress, through drawers. We hear GIRLS CRYING in the next room. They look up, embarrassed, as Jimmy looks in.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You guys almost done?

dialogues.speaker: TROOPER
dialogues.text: Almost, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Find anything?

dialogues.speaker: TROOPER
dialogues.text: Her bankbook. Did you know she closed her account two days ago? Withdrew seven hundred dollars?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: No. No I didn't. As the troopers go back to work and Jimmy walks away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Storefronts shut down across the street. A rumbling stillness has taken over the area. Jimmy steps out on the porch of his three-decker. He sits on the steps. Closing his eyes, he leans back, listens, as the tears of ANNABETH AND HIS DAUGHTERS drift down.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jimmy... Jimmy doesn't hear it at first.  39.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, aim. Jimmy opens his eyes. Standing at the bottom of the steps is Dave. It takes Jimmy a blink or two to recognize him.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Hey, Dave.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I wasn't going to talk to you tonight, but I was out for a walk and saw you sitting here.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: So you know, me and Celeste, the whole neighborhood, if you need anything, anything, we're here.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Appreciate it, Dave. A moment. Dave manages a little smile, a wave.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I'll leave you alone. As Dave starts away.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Dave... Dave stops, looks back hopefully.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know how it is. Irish family. Catholics. How it'll be tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: House full of people all day.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Yeah. All Annabeth has are those ham- fisted brothers of hers. If Celeste could come over and give her a hand...

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Sure, Jimmy. You got it. Dave gives another little wave, starts on his way.  40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Friel stands before a room of eight detectives.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEL
dialogues.text: Powers, where are we so far?

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: Time of death roughly one-fifteen to one- thirty A.M. No sign of sexual assault. Cause of death most likely the gunshot wound to the back of the head, not the trauma from the beating she took. B.P.D. officers are on a house-to-house along Sydney to see if anyone heard anything.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEL
dialogues.text: What else?

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: We're waiting on ballistics... The lack of footprints pisses me off. It rained. Still, she left some, but the perp? Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEL
dialogues.text: What else?

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: She and her friends were bar-hopping. Four places. We're interviewing everyone might've seen or talked to them.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One other thing. Backpack in her car had pamphlets on Las Vegas and a list of Vegas hotels.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEL
dialogues.text: Doesn't sound like much. (looking at Sean) What do you say, Devine?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: We'll get the guy, sir. Friel nods, heads out.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: Four years of college and that's all you could come up with?  4l.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: It made him happy, didn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annabeth and Celeste at the stove, cooking bacon and eggs. Neither talks, but they're happy for each other's company. A HUBBUB of VOICES from the hallway, up which Jimmy walks. Jimmy trades smiles with Celeste, then looks at Annabeth.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You need anything, baby? I can work the stove a bit. Annabeth shakes her head, but doesn't look at him.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABETH
dialogues.text: No, I'm fine. Jimmy looks at Celeste as if to say: Is she?

dialogues.speaker: CELESTE
dialogues.text: We got things covered, Jimmy. Celeste watches as Jimmy looks at his wife. He reaches, wipes a bead of sweat off Annabeth's cheek with his finger.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABETH
dialogues.text: Don't.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Look at me.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABETH
dialogues.text: I can't. Jimmy, if I look at you I'll lose it and I can't lose it with all these people here... Okay?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Okay, baby, okay.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABETH
dialogues.text: I just don't want to lose it again. Celeste wishes she could crawl off, feels like she's looking at them naked, intimate before her.  42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old lady, a busybody. She has one eye on the TV, the other on Sean and Whitey.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PRIOR
dialogues.text: I heard a car hit something.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Hit what, ma'am, another car?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PRIOR
dialogues.text: Oh no, not loud like that.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: Like hitting the curb?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PRIOR
dialogues.text: Yes, maybe. And then it stalled and someone said, 'hi.'

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Someone said, 'hi'?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PRIOR
dialogues.text: Hi. And then there was a loud crack.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Did you ever look out the window, Mrs. Prior?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PRIOR
dialogues.text: Yes, maybe. No. I was in my dressing gown by then. I don't stand in the window in my dressing gown.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: The voice that said, 'hi,' was it male or female?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PRIOR
dialogues.text: Female, I think. Sean looks at Whitey.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Sounds like she knew the shooter.  43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A throng already gathered. Celeste comes out to fill coffee cups. She looks across the room at Dave who's sandwiched between some of the Savage brothers. He sees her, smiles wanly. Very out of his element. And Celeste can feel his aloneness. As she smiles back... The DOORBELL RINGS. Jimmy gets it. It's his father-in- law, THEO SAVAGE, a case of beer on each shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Theo. Jimmy takes one of the cases, as Theo steps inside.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: How's my daughter? How's Annabeth holding up?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: She's trying, Theo.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: (re: beer) Let's get these on ice. You got some coolers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy shakes a bag of ice into a beer cooler; Theo watches.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: How you handling this so far? Jimmy looks up at Theo, not really in the mood.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Hasn't really sunk in, Theo.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Gonna hurt like hell when it does. When my Jane died? I was no good for six months. But my kids were all grown up. I had that luxury. You, you got domestic responsibilities?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Domestic responsibilities?

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Yeah, you know, you gotta take care of my daughter and those little girls. They got to be your priority now.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You figured that might slip my mind, Theo?

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Just needed to be said is all. You'll carry on. 'Cause you're a man. I said to Annabeth, your wedding day, said you got yourself a real old school man there --

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Like they put her in a bag.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: That's what Katie looked like when I saw her in the morgue. Like someone put her in a bag and then had beaten the bag with pipes.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, I, uh --

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Janey died in her sleep. All due respect and shit, but there you go. She went to bed and never woke up. Peaceful.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: You don't need to talk about Janey --

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: My daughter though? Someone put a gun to her. She was murdered. And right about now they'll be starting the autopsy. Laying out scalpels and chest spreaders. And you want to talk to me about my domestic fucking responsibilities? Theo looks down, shuts up finally.  45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crying, holding each other. Eve's FATHER looks on, back behind Sean and Whitey.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Eve, just tell them what they need to know.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Who was she dating?

dialogues.speaker: EVE
dialogues.text: We already told the Savages.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: The Savage brothers?

dialogues.speaker: EVE
dialogues.text: They were here yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: Well, try us out, who was she dating?

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: No one special. Sean plays a hunch.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: You guys had a good-bye dinner, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: EVE
dialogues.text: (busted) What?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: She was leaving town, wasn't she? Going to Las Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: She closed her bankbook, had hotel phone numbers.

dialogues.speaker: EVE
dialogues.text: She wanted out of this dump. She wanted to start a new life.  46. At "life" they start crying again.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: A nineteen-year-old girl doesn't go to Vegas alone. Who was she going with? Come on, Eve, who?

dialogues.speaker: EVE
dialogues.text: Brendan.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Brendan Harris?

dialogues.speaker: EVE
dialogues.text: Brendan Harris. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Just Ray's kid? The one with a mute for a bother? Eve nods.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: You got an address?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy sits on the deck. Sits by himself under the clothesline stretched across the porch. Sits beneath the flapping clothes. The sounds of the WAKE drift out as he stares up at the sky. Dave steps out. Unaware of Jimmy, he steps to the rail, lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Hey, Dave.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (turns; surprised) Hey, Jimmy. Sorry. Came out for a smoke.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: No, no, man. Sit down. Dave sits down alongside Jimmy, backs to the siding.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I haven't had a chance to talk to you all day. How you doing?  47.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: How you doing? Jimmy shrugs. He sees that Dave's right hand is swollen.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: What happened to your hand?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: This? I was helping a buddy move a couch. Slammed it into the doorjamb. Jimmy tilts his head, looks at the badly-scraped knuckles, the bruised flesh between the fingers.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The ways you can manage to hurt yourself, right? Jimmy looks into his face, forgets his hand.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: It's good to see you, man.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: How are our girls holding up?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: They're okay, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Celeste is a godsend. Thank her for me, okay? Dave nods. They sit there in silence a moment.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's nice. Just sitting here.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Jimmy jerks a thumb over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I couldn't take it anymore. Trying to find room in the fridge for all the food we're going to be throwing out in a few days.  48.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: It's a lot of waste, huh?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: But I can't let the things that happen the next few days get fucked up. Because then that's all anyone'll remember about her. Because, Katie, man, one thing you could say about her since she was little, that girl was neat. Dave looks like he's going to cry out of sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That first night out of the joint, after Marita died, I was more afraid of my little daughter than I ever was of being in prison. Fuck... Dave looks pained as the tears roll down Jimmy's cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I loved her the most, because when we sat in the kitchen that first night, we were the last two people on Earth. Forgotten and unwanted. And, Dave, I swear, it's starting to piss me off. I haven't cried yet for her. My own daughter and I can't even cry. Fuck...

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Jim?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: You're crying now.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (realizing) ) Damn...

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Want me to leave you alone?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: No, Dave. Just sit here a minute if that's cool.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Sure, Jim. That's cool.  49.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe the most miserable woman alive. She chain-smokes Parliaments, watches as Sean and Whitey question her son.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: When was the last time you saw Katie Marcus?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: You don't think I hurt her, do you?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: She isn't hurt, Brendan, she's dead.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: I didn't kill her.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: So again, when's the last time you saw her?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Friday night. About, like, eight or so?

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: About like eight, Brendan, or at eight? If it's settled in Jimmy's stomach, it's settled in Brendan's whole body.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: About eight. We had a couple of slices at Hi-Fi. Then she had to go meet Eve and Diane. Brendan looks down. Esther crushes out her cigarette in a pile in the ashtray. Something still burns, a thin stream of smoke, corkscrewing up. As she lights another.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Brendan, Jimmy Marcus doesn't like you. Why?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: I don't know. But he told Katie he never wanted her seeing me or any other Harris.

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: What? That thief thinks he's better than this family?  50.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: He's not a thief.

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: He was a thief. Scumbag burglar. Daughter probably had the same bad gene. Count yourself lucky, Brea. Brendan withers under the harsh words.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: Katie had brochures for Las Vegas. We heard she was going there. With you. As Esther rolls her eyes at the thought, Brendan nods his head. Yes. Esther flinches.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: We were going to leave today. Get married when we got there. Brendan wipes the tears before they can fall.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean, that was the plan, right?

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: You were going to leave me? Without a word?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Ma, I --

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: Just like your father. Huh? At that moment, the front door opens and Silent Ray and his friend JOHN O'SHEA enter, skateboards under their arms.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: This is my brother Ray and his friend John.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: Hey, boys.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Hey. Ray doesn't respond.  51.

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: He don't speak. Father couldn't shut up, but his son is a mute. Oh, yeah, life's fucking fair. Ray's hands fly at Brendan and Brendan nods back.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, they're here about Katie. Go watch TV or something. As the boys ramble out.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: Where were you between twelve-thirty and two this morning?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Asleep.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Can you confirm that, Mrs. Harris?

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: I can confirm he closed his door at ten and showed up for breakfast at nine. I can't confirm he didn't climb out the window and down the fire escape. Brendan just stares at the floor.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: Brendan, we're going to ask you to take a polygraph. You up for that?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: (nods; then) I loved her so much. I, I won't ever feel that again. I mean, it doesn't happen twice, right? He looks up, pain in his eyes you want to duck from.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: It doesn't happen once, most cases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's quiet. Sounds like the crowd is gone. Celeste tidies in the kitchen. Busy work really. Wiping down the toaster, wiping down already clean counters. I'd rather be here than home work.  52. Jimmy enters, is surprised to see her.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Celeste. Celeste jumps, nearly shouts out.

dialogues.speaker: CELESTE
dialogues.text: Sorry, Jimmy. You surprised me.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: What are you still doing here?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (nodding) I convinced her to take a pill. Girls are asleep, too. Jimmy's in here for a reason. He pours himself a shot of whiskey. Celeste watches him. With a wry smile.

dialogues.speaker: CELESTE
dialogues.text: Could I get one of those?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: For the road. Then home.

dialogues.speaker: CELESTE
dialogues.text: I can stay over if you want. Sit up with Annabeth if she wakes up.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: No. You've done enough. Jimmy hands her her shot, raises his.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To you and Dave. For being here for us. They knock back their shots. Celeste sets her glass down.

dialogues.speaker: CELESTE
dialogues.text: I'll come by tomorrow. First thing.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Good night. As she heads out, Jimmy picks up the bottle. About to pour another shot, decides not to. As he screws the cap back on --  53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean sits on the sofa looking through a shoe box of old photos. Mostly him and his wife, Lauren. But there's an older, thicker Polaroid: him, Jimmy and Dave when they were kids. As he stares, BLEED IN the sound of KIDS LAUGHING, the sound of a CAR ROLLING, STOPPING. The PHONE RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Hello? No answer. A FLASH of a WOMAN'S HAND on the other end.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh Christ. Say something, Lauren. He waits, thumbs a picture of his wife. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: SEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm tired of wishing things made sense. Tired of caring about one dead girl because there'll be another one after her. And sending killers to jail is just sending them home. To the place they've been heading all their dumb, pathetic lives. And the dead are still dead. No response. Sean squeezes his eyes shut.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus, I can't do this tonight. I can't do it. He waits a few more seconds, can almost hear her breathing.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bye, baby. As he hangs up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In bed, under the covers, trying to stay awake as his Dad tells him a bedtime story. Dave sits on the edge of the bed, speaking in a hushed tone.  54.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Because sometimes the man wasn't a man at all. He was the boy. The boy who'd escaped from wolves. An animal of the dusk. Invisible. Silent. Living in a world others never saw, a world of fireflies. Unseen except as a flare in the corner of your eye. Vanished by the time you turned your head toward it.'

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: Young Dave runs through the trees. Escaping. Looking like a boy, but sounding like an animal.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Dave looks over at Michael who's now fully asleep. Dave continues, softer now, even more to himself.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I just need to get my head right. Catch a nice long sleep and the boy will go back to his forest. Back to his fireflies.

dialogues.speaker: CELESTE
dialogues.text: Is he asleep? Dave looks up, sees Celeste in the doorway. Dave nods, joins Celeste in...

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: How's Jimmy and everybody?

dialogues.speaker: CELESTE
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: It's weird, took something like this for me and him to become friends again.

dialogues.speaker: CELESTE
dialogues.text: There's still nothing in the paper, Dave.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: About what?  55.

dialogues.speaker: CELESTE
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know, honey. Maybe I didn't hurt the guy as bad as I thought. And he was a mugger; he's not going to the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: CELESTE
dialogues.text: Right. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Anyhow, it doesn't matter, does it? I mean, Katie Marcus is dead, and that seems more important right now. Celeste nods. She starts to reach for him, stops. As she turns and disappears down the hall, Dave watches her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy sits under the clothesline, a pillow in his hand. As he breathes it in and out, we PAN OFF him to... The neighborhood spread out at night. Lights twinkle. Sounds are muted. And in the distance, the Mystic River flows. And over it, we hear:

dialogues.speaker: KATIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Later, Daddy... And then...

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I know in my soul I contributed to your death. I can feel it. But I don't know how.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You will... And as the CAMERA CLOSES ON the river...

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: Brendan Harris aced his polygraph. Four straight times.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Good. I didn't like him for it or want him for it.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: Yeah, poor fucking kid. Whitey starts casting about his desk.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ballistics should be in in a few hours. Meanwhile, we got that list of bar patrons. He finds it, hands Sean a list of about 100 names.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm sure they're all just dying to cooperate with the police.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: (scanning list) Considering the crime, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: (recognizes Dave Boyle) The same guy you were friends with as a kid? The car guy?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Could be.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: He'd be a guy to talk to. He knows you, won't treat us like cops, clam up for no good reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and Dave starts down the front steps with Michael. He stops short as a black unmarked pulls up. Sean and Whitey get out. Sean recognizes Dave.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Dave Boyle. What's it been? Seven, eight years?  57.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Hey, Sean. Stepping forward, Sean shakes his hand. Dave grimaces.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is my son. Michael.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Hey, Michael. I'm Sean, an old buddy of your dad.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: You still with the Staties?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Homicide now. Actually, this is my partner.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: Sergeant Powers. How you doing? Whitey sticks out his hand. Dave shakes it, again trying not to wince.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Dave, you got a minute, we'd love to ask you a couple quick questions.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Actually, I got to walk Michael to school, but I could be back in a few minutes.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Tell you what, we'll walk with you.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Uh, sure. They start walking.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: I hear rents are rising.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They cut my dad's old house up into condos.  58.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Me and Michael walked by there the other day. There's got to be a way to stop them. Friend of mine said the other day, Sean, he said, what this neighborhood needs is a good fucking crime wave. That'd send property values back where they belong.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: Girls keep getting murdered in Pen Park, Mr. Boyle; you might get your wish.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Dave. Call me Dave.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: You said the 'f' word, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Walk up on ahead, Michael. Us guys have to talk. Michael sighs, takes a few steps ahead.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's up, Sean?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: You heard about Katie Marcus?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I was at Jimmy's all day yesterday. Celeste's there now.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: Who's Celeste?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: My wife.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: How's Jimmy doing? Dave's getting a bit frazzled with all the little questions.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Hard to tell. You know him.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: The reason we came by --  59.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I saw her. Katie. I don't know if you know that. At McGill's. The night she died.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Well, yeah, Dave, that's why we're here. They were at a couple of bars that night. Your name showed up on a list of people who were in McGill's.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: We hear she and her friends put on quite a show. Dancing on the bar. They were pretty drunk, huh?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but it was harmless. They weren't stripping or nothing. They were just, nineteen, you know?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: What time did they leave?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I left at one. They left maybe fifteen minutes before me.

dialogues.speaker: WHITEY
dialogues.text: So we'll say twelve-forty-five?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Sounds about right.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: You see anything unusual that night? Anyone?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Guy watching the girls? Guy with black hate in his eyes? Woman hater?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: No. If they hadn't danced on the bar, it would've been business as usual, you know? Sean nods. They've reached the school.  60.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: See you later, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Got your milk money?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Uh huh. Michael runs off to join his friends. An odd moment as Dave watches the laughing, happy kids.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: God, I hated school.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
